metadata.title: Oxidative stress and histological changes in Corbicula fluminea exposed to nano-Al13 and monomeric Al coagulants†

Oxidative stress and histological changes in Corbicula fluminea exposed to nano-Al13 and monomeric Al coagulants†
Yuehan Wu,a Erxue Gu,b Haoxin Li,a Chenghao Tiana and Chenghong Feng *ab
This is the first study to comprehensively analyze the toxicity of Al coagulants, which are widely present in
the effluent of water treatment plants and in natural water in the form of polynuclear Al (e.g., nano-Al13) and mononuclear Al (Alm), on the siphoning efficiency, antioxidant defense system and histological alterations of Corbicula fluminea. The results showed that Alm had a stronger inhibitory effect on siphoning than the nano-Al13 coagulant. For all the selected enzyme indexes, induction by nano-Al13 was more intense in the digestive gland, while that by Alm was more obvious in the gills. Either Alm or nano-Al13 can enlarge the tubule lumen and reduce the thickness of the epithelia of digestive tubules, but nano-Al13 caused more severe damage to the cellular membrane. Inferred from the bright clusters observed by
microscopy, granular nano-Al13 enters the digestive gland mainly via swallowing, while gill filtration is another method by which the ionic Alm can enter the clam body. The presence of nano-Al13 and inhibition of enzymes associated with GSH, such as GST and GR, led to the damage of cell membranes. For both Al co-
agulants, the influence of higher concentrations is more negative. As an effective coagulant, the toxicity of
PACl cannot be ignored.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Al is widely present in the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere. Since the 1980s, a considerable release of Al into the environment has occurred due to acidic precipitation processes, and the toxicity of Al has received increasing attention.1,2 In fact, Al also plays an important role in the daily life of humans, being widely used not only in food additives, pharmaceutical preparations, and specific industrial production processes but also as an essential water treatment material due to its favorable flocculation behavior. The widespread existence and high toxicity of Al have become hot topics in agricultural, geological and environmental research.
Generally, Al can be easily hydrolyzed to various species with different degrees of polymerization. However, most previous studies have focused on monomeric or oligomeric Al.3–6 In the last decade, the use of a new poly Al chloride (PACl) coagulant with an efficient AlO4Al12ĲOH)24ĲH2O)12 7+ (Al13) species was introduced for water treatment. Compared with the traditional Al salt coagulants, which mainly contain monomeric Al (Alm) species, the highly charged Al13
7+ coagulant has high capacity for colloid removal, decolonization and electrical adsorption.7 Moreover, Al13 has been widely used for the treatment of black-colored and odorous water bodies, purification of eutrophic water, and emergency remediation of water pollution. The residual of Al13 is unavoidable. Additionally, considering the widespread distribution of Al, there are also conditions for Al13 formed in natural water conditions.8 Thus, the residual risk of Al13 in the effluents of water treatment plants and the natural environment has always existed.
The granularity of Al13 had been identified as being approximately 2.5 nm, and the particles are combined to form

As a special nanometer material with an electrical charge of septivalence and a special Keggin structure, nano-Al13 coagulants have been extensively produced and applied in the water treatment process in the world. However, the uptake and toxicity mechanism of nano-Al13 is still unclear. Moreover, plenty of research has proved that the aluminum in the aquatic environment poses health risks and the biotoxicity varies from species to species. The controversy on the toxic effect between nano-Al13 and monomeric Al has always been there. Therefore, this study could help in recognizing the biotoxicity of various residual Al species, especially the nano-Al13, in drinking water and the water environment.Pu bl is he d on 0

linear and branched aggregates, the sizes of which usually vary between dozens or hundreds of nanometers, so it was also called nano-Al13.
9 Al13 has the characteristics of coagulants as well as nanoparticles (NPs). The potential effects of NPs have also raised considerable concerns regarding toxicity. NPs can penetrate through biological barriers and be easily transmitted by biological systems.10 To the best of our knowledge, only a few studies have aimed to evaluate the bioavailability and biotoxicity of Alm and nanometer Al13. These studies discovered different impacts of two Al species on glutamate dehydrogenase activity, malate dehydrogenase activity, glutathione reductase (GR) activity, which can also reduce glutathione (GSH) and hemoglobin.11–14 The results reported that nano-Al13 exhibited stronger toxicity than Alm. However, only single enzymes were studied, while studies on the comprehensive response of the enzyme system remained scarce. In practice, oxidative stress-related enzymes, which are important components of the antioxidant defense system, play an important role in the defensive response against the effects of ROS (reactive oxygen species) that can damage lipids, proteins, and DNA.15 In addition, numerous in vivo and in vitro animal experiments have shown that the toxic effects of Al are also closely associated with lipid peroxidation (LPO).3 Thus, oxidative stress-related enzyme activities as well as LPO can provide valuable information regarding the effects of Al13 in the biology of organisms.
Previous researches have demonstrated that when present at a high level, the toxic effects of Al on animals, plants and humans for the ion toxicity stress were attribute to the aqueous Al ion and its hydrolytic species in the environment.4,5 Alm can interact with biological systems and interfere with biological functions, which has been connected to many diseases such as dialysis-associated dementia and microcytic anemia without iron deficiency.6 In fact, as demonstrated by the different crystalloid structures of Al hydrolysates, the mechanisms of biological toxicity of Al species are complex and distinct. It is generally believed that the toxicity of Alm is the highest, followed by that of polymeric Al, while the organic complexes of Al have the lowest toxicity or are basically nontoxic. However, many studies have also shown the opposite results.11,13,14 A previous study indicated that the toxicity of Al13 species against wheat roots is 10 times higher than that of Alm.
16 The morphological toxicity of Al remains to be further demonstrated, and the biological toxicity has barely been evaluated in aquatic organisms.
Among aquatic organisms, Corbicula fluminea is a common freshwater benthic species that is distributed in aquatic ecosystems around the world, directly reflecting the ecosystem contamination in the environment.17 C. fluminea is regarded as a biological invader in some countries, as this species can enter the pipe networks of waterworks.18 This clam can be used as a typical bio-indicator of residual Al risk. Therefore, in this study, C. fluminea clams were continuously exposed to Al13 and Alm, and the sublethal toxicity, siphoning efficiency, and antioxidant defense system were assessed and histological analysis of different tissues was performed. The
main purpose of this study was to better understand the toxicity of nano-Al13. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to comprehensively analyze the biochemical responses of a freshwater bivalve in the presence of a nanometer Al13 coagulant. The findings of this investigation provide a basis for realistic estimations of the environmental risk posed by nano-Al13 coagulants.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preparation of coagulants (Alm and nano-Al13)
sections.text:
In this study, all the reagents were analytical grade chemicals. All the solutions used ultrapure water as the solvent. Mononuclear Al coagulant (Alm) was prepared using AlCl3·6H2O (Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR). Polynuclear Al coagulant (nano-Al13) with an alkalinity (B = [OH−]/[Al]) of a 2.0 was obtained by constantly adding sodium hydroxide solution (NaOH was purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR) dropwise to AlCl3 solution following the method described by Feng. 19 Under the conditions of nitrogen protection and rapid magnetic stirring (the rotation speed was maintained at approximately 500 rpm), the sodium hydroxide solution was added to the AlCl3 solution with a peristaltic pump (YZ1515X, Baoding Constant Current Pump Co.), and the flow rate was 0.15 mL/min. Using a constant-temperature water bath (SENCO, W201, Shanghai) to maintain the reaction temperature at 25 °C. The total Al concentration of both coagulants were measured with an ICP-OES (Perkin-Elmer Co., USA).
In order to prove the existence of different Al species, solutions containing different Al species were examined with a 500 MHz 27Al nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (27Al-NMR, Bruker Co., Germany). The instrumental settings and experimental conditions were P1 = 20 s, PL1 = −3 dB, NS = 128, solvent: D2O, and T = 298 K. The internal standard was a 0.05 mol L−1 AlĲOD)4
− solution, and the chemical shift of this standard was 80 ppm. The signals near 0, 62.5, and 80.0 ppm represent mononuclear Al (Alm) and Al13 ([AlO4Al12(OH)24(H2O)12] 7+).

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization of coagulants (Alm and nano-Al13)
sections.text:
An electrospray ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometer (ESI-TOF-MS, 2695 XE Micro, Waters, USA) was used to further understand the characteristics of each coagulant. The samples were injected into the spectrometer and the flow rate was controlled at 10 μL min−1. The parameters were as follows: capillary voltage 3500.0 V, sample cone voltage 50 V, RF lens 200 V, extraction cone voltage 5 V, source temperature 120 °C, cone gas flow rate 300 L h−1 and mass range 80–1000 u.19
The size of nano-Al13 was measured with an atomic force microscope (AFM), especially. 5 mL sample was absorbed and dropped on a newly cleavaged mica sheet, rinsing with deionized water and drying at room temperature. The dried samples were imaged by Contact mode under AFM. The length of Si3N4 probe was 200 microns and the force constant was 0.12 N m−1. Besides, the particle size distribution of Al13 solution was determined with a laser light scattering analyzer

sections.heading: 2.3 Experimental organism and experimental design
sections.text: Healthy C. fluminea clams were collected from Taizhou County (Zhejiang Province, China) with an average length of 20.56 ± 2.05 mm. Prior to the experiment, the clams were acclimatized in polyethylene plastic containers (previously soaked with hydrochloric acid) with aerated circulating natural water at 24 ± 0.5 °C for 2 weeks in the laboratory. During the acclimatization period, the physical and chemical conditions, such as pH, dissolved oxygen and salinity of water, were held constant, and the clams were fed with dried Spirulina platensis powder (30 mg for each individual) per day. The adult C. fluminea clams were selected to be acclimated for 2 days in dechlorinated tap water for testing. To reduce interference with the results, the clams were not fed during the experimentation period. Dead C. fluminea clams were removed in a timely manner to maintain adequate dissolved oxygen levels.

sections.heading: 2.4 Experimental design
sections.text:
The C. fluminea clams were exposed to mononuclear Al (AlCl3) and polynuclear Al (PACl) at 0, 1.35, and 100 mg L −1 for 10 days. High exposure concentrations of toxicants are often used in laboratory experiments to elicit obvious distinguishable effects and to determine the possible toxicity mechanisms.20 The concentration of Al salt coagulants used in this study was selected on base of the extreme residual condition of the application. The low concentration was selected as 1.35 ppm in order to simulate the maximum concentration of residual aluminum in pipe network, which was inferred from our previous investigation (to be published). The high concentration as 100 ppm (a maximum nonlethal concentration in our previous experiment) was aim to simulate another Al residual situation: short-term and large-scale application of Al coagulant in treatment of black and odorous water. In addition, the hydrochloric acid-treated group, the pH of which was consistent with the pH of the solution after hydrolysis of the Al salt coagulant, served as the pH control
for each group. There were three replicate 6 L glass aquariums in each treatment group, and each aquarium contained 80 clams. The conditions were as follows: temperature of 24 ± 1 °C and oxygen saturation of 96% ± 2%. The water was changed slowly every day without moving the clams, and the clams were sampled after 0, 1, 3, 7, and 10 days of exposure. No clams died during the test (Table 1).

sections.heading: 2.5 Sublethal toxicity assay
sections.text:
At each sampling time, 15 C. fluminea clams were removed from each group for examination of burrowing behavior. Then, the siphoning efficiency of five clams was determined; two clams were fixed in formalin (10%) for preparation of digestive gland cell sections; and the remaining eight clams were stored for subsequent enzyme-based assays of subchronic toxicity.
C. fluminea clams live on the bottom of the water and filter the food in the water through their suckers. The siphoning index of clams has been studied previously to monitor environmental pollutants in water. This method is mainly based on the method of Cooper and Bidwell.21 On the 10th day of chemical exposure, five C. fluminea clams were moved to a 500 mL beaker with 300 mL solution of a neutral red (1 mg L−1) to assess the siphoning rate in triplicate. The absorbance of neutral red solution (1 mg L−1) was determined before the experiment at 530 nm with a spectrophotometer. After two hours of the test, 1 mL of sample solution was sampled from each beaker with a short time, and the absorbance was also gained by spectrophotometer at 530 nm. The absorbance was calculated into the neutral red concentration based on a standard curve for the concentrations of neutral red standard solutions. The calculating method of filtration rate for C. fluminea in each treatment group was selected according as Cooper and Bidwell's equation (mL per animal per h):21

sections.heading: 2.6 Subchronic toxicity assay
sections.text:
2.6.1 Biochemical analysis Tissue preparation. After rinsing the shells with deionized water, different organs (gills and digestive glands) were separated by clean forceps and a scalpel and then homogenized in three times (by weight) as much ice-cold PBS (phosphate-buffered saline, prepared fresh) by ultra-sonication. The homogenate was then centrifuged in a high-speed refrigerated centrifuge at 3500 r min−1 for 15 min (4 °C), and the supernatants were collected to analyze the activities of four biochemical indicators. To prevent temperature from affecting the enzyme activity, the entire experiment was carried out under low-temperature conditions (ice water bath). Each treatment group was evaluated in triplicate.
Antioxidant enzyme activity and MDA assay. Antioxidant enzyme activities and MDA levels in C. fluminea were measured as described by Chen et al. (2015).22 The protein content of each sample was measured according to the instructions provided with the Protein Assay Kit (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, China). The supernatant was frozen at −80 °C for further analysis. According to the manufacturer's protocols, the activities of antioxidant enzymes and MDA levels were analyzed using the respective assay kits (SOD, GST, GR and MDA: Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, China).
2.6.2 Histological analysis. Subsamples of bivalve tissues were processed for histological analysis by Hematoxylin–eosin (H–E) staining. After being fixed in 10% formalin solution for over 48 h (Panreac, Spain), the samples were washed in distilled water and then dehydrated with a 70% (v/v) ethanol solutions (Scharlau, Australia) and xylene (Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR). Then, the samples were embedded in paraffin for histological sectioning. Sections of 5–7 μm were mounted on glass slides and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).10,23 Histological observation was performed using an optical microscope (Xipaike L135, Xipaike optical instrument Co., Ltd, Shenzhen, China) with an assembled digital camera.

sections.heading: 2.7 Statistical analysis
sections.text: The test results were obtained using the average and standard deviation (X + SD), and single-factor analysis of variance and correlation analysis of the data were performed by using SPSS 20.0 statistical software. The differences between the experimental groups and the control group were verified by paired sample T test. Multiple comparison test (LSD) showed significant differences between groups, and significant differences were assessed at a level of 0.05 (P < 0.05 represents a significant difference/correlation, as indicated by asterisk (*)).

sections.heading: 2.8 Laboratory animal ethics statement
sections.text:
The experimentation, transportation and use of the animals were performed in compliance with the relevant laws and institutional guidelines. The experimentation, transportation and use of the animals (Corbicula fluminea) were performed
in accordance with the Guidelines for Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of Beijing Normal University and approved by the Ethics Committee for Aquatic Animal of Chinese Association for Laboratory Animal Sciences (CALAS). The procedures were performed in compliance with the Animal Management Regulations in China.

sections.heading: 3.1 Sublethal effects of Alm and nano-Al13 on siphoning
sections.text:
Testing of acute toxicity, especially lethality, can reflect the most direct effect of toxicants on organisms and is the most common method used in toxicity assays. However, clams exhibit relatively high adaptability, even in severely polluted environments. Observation of behaviors such as siphoning is suitable for toxicity studies under most pollution conditions. Previous studies have demonstrated that bivalve siphoning can be influenced by metals or chlorpyrifos.21 As a response to chemical stress, reduction in siphoning activity was attributed to ammonia accumulation in the tissue, reduction in oxygen exchange and reduced feeding.24 Owing to the importance of siphoning for nutritional physiology, defense, and reproductive mechanisms in bivalves, siphoning behavior has become an important indicator of general health or stress, and observation of this behavior has been proposed as a biomonitoring approach.22,25
The effects of Al species and acidity on the siphoning behavior of C. fluminea are illustrated in Fig. 1(A and B) and (C and D), respectively. It can be inferred that the siphoning efficiency of C. fluminea in the medicated groups was generally lower than that in the control groups (p < 0.05), and the siphoning efficiency decreased with prolonged exposure time. This finding indicated that the presence of the Al coagulant did inhibit the siphoning behavior of C. fluminea (Fig. 1A and B). However, there was no obvious significant difference observed in the siphoning behavior between mononuclear Al (Alm) and polynuclear Al (nanoAl13) under low-concentration treatments (1.35 mg L
−1; Fig. 1A). The filtration rates of individual clams among these groups ranged from 20.67 to 23.34 mL per animal per h. Moreover, significant differences (p < 0.05) were observed when the exposure concentration of Al was high (100 mg L−1; Fig. 1B), and the filtration rate of calms under exposure to Alm coagulant (4.76 ± 2.16 mL per animal per h) obviously decreased, compared to the control group (26.85 ± 2.61 mL per animal per h) (p < 0.05). All the phenomena indicated that a high concentration of Al coagulant has a highly negative effect on the behaviors of C. fluminea. Similar findings were also observed upon exposure to other compounds.26,27 Fig. 1(B) clearly shows that Alm had a stronger inhibitory effect on siphoning than the nano-Al13 coagulant. Since C. fluminea filtered foods from water through siphon to complete material exchange,28 the reduction of siphoning is an expression of self-protection mechanism in the short term, which could affect the activity of enzymes in antioxidant defense system by influencing the body's closed shell stress

In subsequent articles, we connected the exposure level reflected by siphoning with the toxic effects reflected by enzymatic activity to investigate if there is a link.
To determine whether the inhibition of siphoning in C. fluminea was affected by the acidity caused by hydrolysis of the two Al coagulants, an Al-free control group with a pH similar to those of the Alm coagulant (pH = 3.60, resulting from Al hydrolysis) and the Al13 coagulant (pH = 4.56, resulting from Al hydrolysis) was also studied (Fig. 1C and D). Similar to the Al coagulant, the presence of acidity significantly affects the siphoning behavior of the bivalve. Although the siphoning efficiency of C. fluminea was significantly inhibited when the aqueous solution was acidic (p < 0.05), more clear and substantial decreases were observed upon exposure to Al coagulants with the same pH values (Fig. 1C and D).
Moreover, Fig. 1(C) and (D) indicate that the siphoning behavior of C. fluminea was severely damaged even 1 day after Alm treatment (the siphoning efficiency was as low as 6.83 mL per animal per h). During the whole exposure time, Alm exhibited lower siphoning efficiency than the Al13 coagulant. This finding indicated that the toxic effect of mononuclear Al was higher than that of polynuclear Al NPs, which is consistent with the results drawn from the comparison of different Al concentrations (Fig. 1A and B). Moreover, the minimum value appeared at 10 days in Alm treatment group under high concentrations (100 mg L−1; Fig. 1D), which was 3.76 times lower than the value for the pH control group, further dem-
onstrating that Alm had a stronger inhibitory effect on C. fluminea siphoning than Al13.
There also exists a unique phenomenon that occurs in the first 3 days; the siphoning efficiency of C. fluminea increased after Al coagulant, especially the nano-Al13 coagulant, was added (Fig. 1C). This finding could explain how C. fluminea could rapidly adapt to the environment at the initial stage. By increasing the filtration speed, the exchange with the environmental media of C. fluminea was increased to eliminate interference. However, the health of the clams was seriously damaged after 7 days, becoming increasingly difficult to recover with prolonged exposure time.25 In fact, as for the control groups, siphoning behaviors also had a slight fluctuation with exposure time. This effect might be connected with the starvation during the experiment.30 However, the impact of changes in siphoning behavior of control groups is generally negligible.

sections.heading: 3.2 Antioxidant defense-related enzymatic activities and lipid peroxidation
sections.text:
Generally, the effects of xenobiotic manifest as imbalance in antioxidant and fatty acid metabolism systems.31 Previous studies have shown that exposure to diamond NPs, TiO2 NPs and halogen-free organophosphorus flame retardants can induce oxidative effects in whole soft tissues of C. fluminea.10,26,32–34 However, few studies have assessed the possible differences in antioxidative stress response among various bivalve organs, and the mechanisms have not been well explained. Previous studies have demonstrated that the number and type of enzymes were clearly different among various organs, such as gills and digestive glands.35 And the exposure path and distribution of contaminants were different. Therefore, increased attention should be paid to antioxidant defense-related enzymatic activities and LPO in various bivalve organs.
According to our previous review and research, SOD, GST, GR, and LPO (MDA levels) were optimized and selected as typical indexes to evaluate antioxidant defense-related enzymatic activities and LPO.25 The activities of SOD, GST, and GR and MDA content were measured in gill and digestive gland tissue isolated from all the treatment groups and are presented in Fig. 2. The associations of the antioxidant defense-related enzyme system are also described in Fig. 3.
SOD is the first line of defense and is the primary antioxidant enzyme responsible for eliminating excess ROS by transforming ROS to H2O2.
36 For most treatment groups, the SOD activity increased at first, followed by a slight decrease with prolongation of reaction time. Moreover, there were no significant differences among the treatment groups at low concentrations of both coagulants (T2 and T3), but there were significant differences in response to 100 mg L−1 Al (T4 and T5). A rapid increase could be observed with increasing exposure time (7 days), and the highest level of SOD activity was observed in digestive glands in the nano-Al13 coagulant treatment group (Fig. 2A: T4) and in gills in the Alm coagulant treatment group (Fig. 2B: T5) after 7 days of exposure. This finding indicates that the presence of Al enhanced the

enhances the regulatory functions of the organism and ultimately influences SOD synthesis.38 It has also been reported that heavy metals could replace the metal in the active center of SOD (Cu/Zn-SOD, Fe-SOD, Mn-SOD), changing the structure of SOD and leading to a decrease in or even inactivation of enzyme activity;25 Al might also play a similar role.
GSTs constitute a family of phase II enzymes and are involved in peroxide elimination and detoxification. GST can conjugate electrophilic compounds with GSH and participate in cellular protection against the toxic effects of a range of xenobiotic and oxidative metabolic byproducts.39 GSH is also an important component of the cell membrane. Compared with the control group (T1), the activity of GST increased significantly during the early stage to alleviate the damage caused by rapidly the increasing free radicals under relatively low Al coagulant concentrations. This phenomenon was more obverse in the digestive glands in response to Al13 nanoparticles (Fig. 2C, T2, 1–3d) while more distinct in the gills of the Alm coagulant groups (Fig. 2D, T3, 1–3d). Subsequently, GST activity was inhibited during the late stage, which was also significant in the same groups (T2 and T3 in Fig. 2C) because of severe damage caused to bodily health. However, GST activity was downregulated in both organs of clams under relatively high Al concentrations at the first stage, and a clear increase was observed after 7 days, which was most likely associated with the stress tolerance response. The clam body responded by attempting to reduce exposure levels.
GR is an important cellular antioxidant.40 Similar to SOD, the synthesis of GR is regulated by oxidative stress caused by exposure to high concentrations of ROS.41 GR can regenerate GSH from glutathione disulfide (GSSG), so a decrease in GR levels will directly result in a substantial decrease in GSH levels (Fig. 3).42 Compared with the control group (T1), GR activity was downregulated at both concentrations of the Al13 coagulant in the digestive glands of the clams (Fig. 2E, T2 and T4) but was upregulated in the presence of the Alm coagulant (Fig. 2E, T3 and T5). In the gills, the GR levels increased slightly at both Al13 concentrations and, to a greater extent, in response to the Alm coagulant (Fig. 2F, T3 and T5). For all the treatment groups, a significant reduction could be observed during the experimental process.
Two possible reasons for the observed decrease are as follows: (i) an adaptive response to stress via the use of other
defense mechanisms, such as the latter induction of stress proteins or nonenzymatic antioxidant activities. (ii) Exhaustion of the organism's defenses under severe stress.43 The sharp changes in GST and GR levels in both digestive glands and gills during the reaction period indicated that these alterations were ascribed to the latter. After entry of the xenobiotic into the body, reactive oxygen free radicals were produced to activate the synthesis of antioxidant enzymes, and the activity of the enzymes increased. However, the enzyme activity was inhibited as the concentration of pollutants gradually increased. Because of the strong toxic effect, the balance of the antioxidant system was disrupted, so the groups in which enzymatic activity was inhibited exhibited a greater toxic effect than groups in which enzymatic activity was induced. This result is consistent with the result of the SOD activity analysis.
As one of the decomposition products of unsaturated fatty acid peroxides, MDA has the ability to severely damage cell membranes. MDA content measuring can indirectly evaluated the LPO.44 A previous study indicated that Al can promote the LPO of brain tissue, which is one of the important mechanisms underlying the chronic neurotoxicity of Al.45 As inferred from Fig. 2(G) and (H), a gradual elevation in MDA content in gills and digestive glands was recorded in response to Al coagulant with increasing time and concentration. The lowest value was detected in the control groups (1.69 M mg−1 total protein), while almost all the MDA content increased to the highest value after 10 days of exposure. These results indicate the existence of oxidative stress in the two tissues. Similar increases in LPO were reported for mollusks in the presence of high Cd concentrations (1.1–5.6 mg L−1).46,47 Moreover, as indicated by the rectangles, induction by nano-Al13 is stronger in the digestive glands (Fig. 2G: T2, T4), while induction by Alm is higher in gills (Fig. 2H: T3, T5), which is consistent with the results of the antioxidant enzyme system tests.

sections.heading: 3.3 Histological alterations of the digestive gland upon exposure to Alm and nano-Al13
sections.text:
Generally, tissue structure analysis is the most fundamental method in toxicological research. Histological, histochemical, histopathological evaluations and analysis of the morphological alterations of the digestive gland are often used to investigate the response to pollutants. In fact, histological studies on the effect of Al on cells of freshwater bivalves are scarce, and current studies mainly focus on the effects of some pollutants on marine bivalves.48 To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to show histological alterations in the digestive gland of a freshwater bivalve with exposure to Alm and nano-Al13 coagulants.
Regarding the organs of C. fluminea, the digestive glands of bivalves play a vital role in the regulation and elimination of xenobiotic, being the primary organs for metabolism and accumulation. The epithelial cells lining the tubules of the digestive gland are sensitive to the damaging effects of many

pollutants, such as metals and metalloids.49 Therefore, the digestive gland profiles of C. fluminea were analyzed to further identify the histological alterations of the Alm and nanoAl13 coagulants.
As shown in Fig. 4①, the structure of the healthy organ consists of digestive tubules formed by a single layer of cells with an occulted lumen (as indicated by “*” in Fig. 4①), which exhibits regular “Y”-shaped physalides (as shown in Fig. 4①). However, after 10 days of exposure to either the Alm or nano-Al13 coagulant, widening or enlargement of the tubule lumen and a reduction in epithelia thickness of the digestive tubules were observed (Fig. 4②–⑤), which indicates that both the Alm and nano-Al13 coagulants triggered an inflammatory response in the digestive gland of the bivalve with increasing exposure time. Similar results were observed upon exposure to other metal pollutants (e.g., AsĲIII), Cu, Cd), TiO2 nanoparticles, diamond nanoparticles and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).10,32,50 In addition, the internal organelles of some cells flowed out (Fig. 4③ and ⑤), and this phenomenon was not observed in the groups exposed to acidic conditions (Fig. 4② and ④), indicating the occurrence of cellular membrane damage. Moreover, the degree of outflow shown in ③ in Fig. 4 is greater than that in ⑤, which indicates that nano-Al13 causes more severe damage to the cellular membrane than Alm. Perhaps the larger molecular size and higher positive charge of Al13 than those of Alm is the main reason.19 Overall, the morphological changes in digestive gland cells are consistent with the results from the analyses of oxidative stress enzymes and LPO. Notably, some active enzymes associated with GSH, such as GST and GR, in the antioxidant defense system are closely related to the maintenance of cell membrane integrity.51
Moreover, nanoparticles have been proved to enter digestive gland cells and even organelles of blue mussels and cockles by endocytosis.34 These particles can penetrate through biological barriers and move easily within biological
systems, which have negative effects on organisms. Fig. 4③ shows that many subtle bright clusters were visible inside or beside cells analyzed by light microscopy, which were probably formed by agglomerated nanoparticles (i.e., clusters of Al13). A similar result was also obtained in the presence of nano-TiO2.
10 Nano-Al13 might also have the ability to cross the membrane into cells. However, there was no mechanistic information regarding the entry of these special nano-Al13 particles through the cell membranes, which might have a direct destructive effect on cell membranes (as inferred from the comparison of ③ and ⑤ in Fig. 4). Some subtle bright clusters were also observed in Fig. 4⑤. This observation can be explained by the fact that for Alm, the pH of freshwater or in vivo can easily result in polymerization to nano-Al13 or other nanoscale Al clusters with increased polymerization occurring after entry into C. fluminea via the gills or swallowing. This explanation is consistent with the outflow of the internal organelles of some cells, as shown in Fig. 4⑤. Additionally, under low magnification, some cell clusters were seen to aggregate (as shown in the lower-left corner in Fig. 4③ and ⑤). The excellent flocculation behavior of Al13 with a high positive charge (+7) should be the main reason. This finding also proves the existence of Al13 inside or beside the cells.

sections.heading: 3.4 Differences in toxicological mechanism between Alm and nano-Al13
sections.text:
To better understand the bioavailability and toxicity of Al clusters in the coagulant, the Al speciation of the two coagulants was analyzed with a 27Al-NMR spectrometer and ESITOF-MS spectrometer. 27Al-NMR can give information of specific Al morphology and structure in hydrolyzed Al solution quantitatively and nondestructively. As shown in Fig. 5(a), an incisive peak was observed by 27Al-NMR at 62.5 ppm in PACl, proving the presence of Keggin-Al13 structure ([AlO4Al12ĲOH)24ĲH2O)12] 7+),52 and the content of Al13 reached 82.76%

(shown in the inserted table). For the AlCl3 coagulant, only monomeric Al (the peak at 0 ppm) was detected with the 100% content of Alm. To further distinguish the Al species in two coagulants, the ESI-TOF-MS was utilized to reveal the distributions of Al clusters after dosage in aqueous. The results shown in Fig. 5(b) and (c) demonstrate that the dominant species in AlCl3 are Al1 +, Al2 +, Al3 + and Al4 + (Fig. 5b), while the dominant species in PACl are Al13, including Al13 2+ and Al13 3+ (Fig. 5c). As a newly developed soft ionization analysis technology, the ESI-TOF-MS can keep compounds from being destroyed in the ionization process, thus obtaining more accurate molecular weight information. Molecular formulas of various forms of metals can be determined by mass-charge ratio (m/z) information in the spectra. Obviously, great difference between the distribution of the peaks and the corresponding m/z was observed for the two coagulants. Moreover, it can be inferred that the molecular weights of hydrolytic clusters in AlCl3 and PACl coagulants are between 97 to 373 Da and 639 to 909 Da, respectively.
The nanometer particle size characteristics of the PACl coagulant was also analyzed with atomic force microscope (AFM, Fig. 6a) and laser light scattering analyzer (LLS, Fig. 6b). As shown in Fig. 6(a), the morphology of Al13 on the mica interface shown by AFM were branched or compactly packed aggregates consisting of discrete spherical nanoparticles of 10–20 nm, proving the nanostructure is stable. In fact, the particle size distribution of Al13 was between 1.0–2.0 nm, and the peak was observed at 1.33 nm by LLS. The differences between the particle sizes of the two techniques was mainly ascribed to the measurement condition. For AFM, the dry condition at room temperature encourages the aggregation of Al13, and the observed particles in AFM are Al13 aggregates. Even so, it is undeniable that the two techniques both prove the nanometer size characterization of Al13 and the speciation differences between Al13 and Alm.

toxicity and tissue toxicity effects of Al. It can be inferred from Fig. 1 that the results for sublethal toxicity (behavioral effect) were clearly different from those for cytotoxicity. With increasing Alm or Al13 concentrations, the siphoning behavior of clams exhibited an immediate response to stress, indicates that clams have the ability to alleviate damage. The stronger the inhibition of siphoning is, the lower the chance of coming in contact with Al coagulants. Notably, the inhibition of siphoning by the Alm coagulant was more intense than that by nano-Al13 (as inferred from Fig. 1(B), which affects the subsequent behavior of clams with prolonged exposure time. There are two possible explanations for this phenomenon. One explanation is that the stress tolerance response in the late stage is stronger than that in the early stage, and the other explanation is that the health of C. fluminea is severely damaged. If the former is true, then the exposure level of clam bodies to Alm was lower than that to nano-Al13 as the reaction time was prolonged. The damage caused to the antioxidant system in the Al13 experimental groups was greater than that in the Alm groups. In healthy clams, the enzymatic activity should return to normal gradually with increasing exposure time. However, based on the experimental results, substantial changes were observed for the antioxidant enzyme system, which indicated that the balance of the antioxidant defense system in the clams had been destroyed. The stress protection mechanism no longer has sufficient effect. Moreover, the siphoning behavior of the clams did not return to the normal level (experiment not shown) with prolonged exposure time. Therefore, the first conjecture can be excluded. Thus, although the siphoning behavior reduced the exposure to pollutants in the late stage, the early exposure irreversibly damaged the health of C. fluminea.
Several toxicological endpoints were also observed and were triggered by either the Alm or nano-Al13 coagulant: (i) distinct inhibitory effect on siphoning behaviors, (ii) slight increase or decrease in the activities of antioxidant enzymes in presence of Al, (iii) significant increase in LPO in presence of Al, and (iv) morphological changes in the digestive gland for all treatments with extension of exposure time. All the toxicological endpoints indicated that the oxidative stress was
caused by the experimental conditions, and the toxicity of two Al species on different organs was different. For all three antioxidant enzymes, the toxic effects of nano-Al13 were more intense in the digestive glands, while those of Alm were more obvious in the gills. These results provide additional insights into the relationship between the effect and concentration of Al and exposure time, which is most likely explained by the toxicity mechanism. The differences might be associated with the toxicity pathways of the two Al coagulants. Filtration is the main eating channel of C. fluminea. However, in order to maintain the high energy requirement of metabolism, valves must be open to increase the ingestion.53 In water environment, the closure duration of valves would no longer than seven minutes.54 Gills are gas-exchanging organs and are directly exposed to water contaminants.34 The main foods of C. fluminea are suspended matter, organic matter and plankton in the water, the intake of which occurs mainly via absorption of water through gills as well as via swallowing of particulate matter. It could be speculated that the entry of granular nano-Al13 into the digestive gland occurs mainly via swallowing, while gill filtration is another method for the entry of the ionic Alm into the C. fluminea body.
21 This phenomenon was observed at both low and high concentrations of the two Al coagulants, and the distinct toxicity of the low concentration was probably associated with hormesis. Previous research has also shown that toxic effect of dehydrogenase activity varies with pH. The effect of nano-Al13 on dehydrogenase activity was the strongest, probably because of the highly reactive sites of Al13 clusters, leading to strong biological interactions.55 In addition, nanoscale metals are themselves toxic to aquatic organisms. Most studies have shown that these toxic effects may be caused by the joint action of metal ions releasing. The active center of GR is rich in sulfhydryl groups, which can bind to metal ions to inhibit enzymatic activity.55 The Alm and nano-Al13 coagulants might have strong inhibitory effects on GR activity, which is associated with the coordination of Al and ligands, changing the conformation of enzymes.56 It was found that the Al clusters are charged and might react with the active center of the antioxidant enzyme, which could also be closely associated

Based on the experimental data, it could also be deduced that the cell damage shown in Fig. 4 might be a result of lipid peroxidation being directly associated with the degree of membrane damage. The toxicological differences among the various experimental groups could be directly deduced from the change in MDA levels. The results were the same as those observed for cell morphology (T4 > T5). In addition, the clusters observed inside the cells were probably a result of the transmembrane entry of nanoparticle Al clusters into cells. However, the specific transmembrane mechanism was not clear, and it was not known whether the seven-valence charge of Al13 would affect the integrity of the cell membrane. The interaction of various factors led to a change in cell morphology. Moreover, GSH is a component of cell membranes, and changes in GST and GR, which are associated with GSH production and consumption, also affect the integrity of cell membranes.
Nevertheless, a different result could be obtained by performing subchronic or chronic exposure. This phenomenon was not considered in this work because it is essential to feed the clams during the experiment, however, that would bring in additional organic and inorganic particles (components of the food source) in the exposure medium. These particles would change the speciation as well as the characteristics of the Al cluster undoubtedly, further affecting the availability of Al.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The response of antioxidant enzymes to two typical Al salt coagulants was compared among different tissues of C. fluminea, and the toxicity mechanism was also discussed. Exposure to the nano-Al13 and Alm coagulants caused suppression of siphoning, a stress oxidation response and an increase in lipid peroxidation (MDA content), indicating cell membrane damage. The siphoning behavior under pressure led to the decrease in the exposure level, which would further affect the activity of antioxidant defense enzymes. Whether with exposure to high or low concentrations, nano-Al13 exhibited heightened toxicity especially for specific organs (digestive glands). Its potential health effect cannot be ignored. The results are compatible with the histological alterations observed in the epithelial cells of the digestive gland. The concentration of Al salt coagulants used in this study was selected on base of the extreme residual condition of Al coagulant application and much higher than the usual situation, which could better explain the toxic mechanism and simulate environmental release of such material into aquatic ecosystems during emergencies. Further research should be performed with a special focus on the use of environmentally relevant concentrations with lower concentrations or longer exposure periods than those used in this study.

metadata.abstractText: This is the first study to comprehensively analyze the toxicity of Al coagulants, which are widely present in the effluent of water treatment plants and in natural water in the form of polynuclear Al (e.g., nano-Al13) and mononuclear Al (Alm), on the siphoning efficiency, antioxidant defense system and histological alterations of Corbicula fluminea. The results showed that Alm had a stronger inhibitory effect on siphoning than the nano-Al13 coagulant. For all the selected enzyme indexes, induction by nano-Al13 was more intense in the digestive gland, while that by Alm was more obvious in the gills. Either Alm or nano-Al13 can enlarge the tubule lumen and reduce the thickness of the epithelia of digestive tubules, but nano-Al13 caused more severe damage to the cellular membrane. Inferred from the bright clusters observed by microscopy, granular nano-Al13 enters the digestive gland mainly via swallowing, while gill filtration is another method by which the ionic Alm can enter the clam body. The presence of nano-Al13 and inhibition of enzymes associated with GSH, such as GST and GR, led to the damage of cell membranes. For both Al coagulants, the influence of higher concentrations is more negative. As an effective coagulant, the toxicity of PACl cannot be ignored.
